subject: Re: [junit] Re: Testing Struts with Mock Objects
msgSnippet: Definitely think it would be useful. Thanks. ... -- Bryce Fischer
messageBody:
Definitely think it would be useful.

Thanks.


> We have used StrutsTestCase successfully on several medium- to large-
> sized web projects with good success.
>
> To overcome the problem you talk about (as well as other related
> ones), I have a custom subclass of MockStrutsTestCase that allows me
> to (optionally) set the action object I want the test to use.
>
> .public class AbstractStruts11TestCase extends MockStrutsTestCase {
> .
> . /**
> . * Allow using a different action. Checks to see if this action
> . * is assignment-compatbile with the action class mapped in
> . * struts-config.
> . */
> . protected void setAction(Action other) {
> . String theActionPath = (String) getField("actionPath");
> . theRequestProcessor.setOverrideAction(other, theActionPath);
> . }
>
>
> This turns out to be very useful in a variety of situations. I can
> subclass the Actions under test to override certain methods, etc.
>
> We also use this subclass to disable/enable the struts auto-
> validation of form beans. Sometimes you just want to test the action
> processing without worrying about if the form is valid or not.
>
> I would be happy to send you the code if you think this would be
> useful.
>
> Jeff Nielsen
> Digital Focus
> www.digitalfocus.com
>
>
> --- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Bryce Fischer <bryce@b...> wrote:
> > I've posted a similar question on the Struts list, but maybe its
> more
> > appropriate for this list.
> >
> > I'm trying to determine the best way to test my Struts Actions. I've
> > come across 2 projects that look interested.
> >
> > 1. StrutsTestCase (http://strutstestcase.sourceforge.net/)
> > and
> > 2. Mockrunner (http://mockrunner.sourceforge.net/)
> >
> > I like the simplicity of StrutsTestCase. I'm using a delegate in my
> > Action case, and would like to use a MockObject in place of the
> delegate
> > class. This way I could simulate exceptions, etc...
> >
> > Unfortunately, I have been unable to devise a method to tell my
> Action
> > object what delegate class I'd like to use.
> >
> > One idea would be to put the delegate class in the request
> parameter.
> > This would be easy to do in StrutsTestCase, but I'm not sure how
> this
> > would work in a Live system. How would I get the delegate class
> into the
> > request?
> >
> > Any other suggestions?
> >
> > --
> > Bryce Fischer <bryce@b...>
>
